SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a leading cause of sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia in the pediatric population
This study aimed to determine risk factors for the presence of LQTS-related symptoms in a single pediatric center
METHODS AND RESULTS: Subjects were 146 consecutive LQTS patients (M:F= 72:74) who visited our hospital between April 2005 and August 2012 and during the preceding 24 months
103 subjects were discovered by the school-based screening, 15 subjects visited because of their symptoms, and the others were 28 subjects
Risk factors for the presence of symptoms after diagnosis were longer QTc values (p=0.01), the presence of past history of LQTS-related symptoms (p=0.04), and longer follow-up periods (p=0.03)
Noncompliance with medicine was the sole risk factor for frequent symptoms after diagnosis (p=0.02)
In subjects discovered by the school-based screening, 9 subjects (9%) had LQTS-related symptoms after diagnosis
Longer follow-up periods was the sole risk for the presence of symptoms (p=0.04)
The mean period until the presence of symptoms after diagnosis was 3.1 Â± 2.7 year (0.1-7.1 year)
CONCLUSION: Good compliance with medicine is essential to prevent recurrent episodes
A new strategy is required to keep on following-up subjects for long time though subjects discovered by the school-based screening
